Award.AwardTitle: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: Ship-based Technical Support in the Arctic
Award.AbstractNarration: This proposal requests support to augment the marine research technical services provided by the U.S. Coast Guard (USCG) on their icebreakers for research cruises in the arctic region. This proposal is a collaborative between the Shipboard Technical Support (STS) department at Scripps Institution of Oceanography (SIO) and the Marine Technician Group (MTG) at Oregon State University (OSU) to provide the highest level of shipboard technical support possible. The proposal will use a model for arctic shipboard technical support that follows best practices of the University-National Oceanographic Laboratory System (UNOLS) fleet. An Arctic Cruise Coordinator will be recruited with the exclusive responsibility for creating and overseeing a precruise planning process based on existing SIO and OSU methods, modified to suit the needs of scientists sailing on the USCG cutters in the arctic. The Coordinator will work with all parties to develop efficient staffing and equipment assignments customized for each cruise leg, and develop an annual technical support budget (under the supervision of the STS manager) that will be submitted to NSF. If the requirements for an Arctic cruise cannot be met using the available resources of SIO and OSU, then the Coordinator will solicit marine technical support from other UNOLS institutions. Education and training of students, new technicians and USCG personnel in use of technology and techniques at sea is part of the broader impacts of this proposal, thus broadening the technical knowledge base that supports U.S. oceanographic research. SIO will support the acquisition and appropriate handling of underway shipboard data in concert with national data centers such as the NSF-supported R2R program, making data available to the academic community and the public at large. SIO and OSU will coordinate with NSF, USCG and the Arctic Icebreaker Coordinating Committee to define priorities for maintenance and upgrades to science equipment onboard.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This is a collaborative award between established shipboard technical support groups at Oregon State University and Scripps Institution of Oceanography (UC San Diego). The two groups received separate awards and so this report deals exclusivley with the work performed by Scripps and accounting for the funds received for this effort.

This grant provided funding to augment the research support provided by the US Coast Guard to scientists sailing on ice breakers in the Arctic region. The primary ship is the USCG Cutter HEALY. The ship began service in 2000. There is berthing space for up to 51 scientists and more than 390 square meters of scientific laboratory space. The ice breaker is equipped with scienitific instrumentation equivalent to other ships in the US academic fleet (UNOLS).

A key element of the support offered to the US Coast Guard  is the designation of an Arctic Cruise Coordinator, who serves as a single point of contact for principal investigators, participating scientists, ship operator (e.g. US Coast Guard), and funding agency program managers. The Coordinator is a senior Scripps technician who is devoted full-time to lead the effort for planning, coordination and reporting of research support activities for Arctic cruises. The Coordinator calls on the experience and expertise of supervisors within SIO/STS and OSU/MTG to assist in carrying out these duties to the highest standard. The Coordinator serves important functions from the earliest pre-cruise planning stages all the way through final reporting.

An important aspect of the work is the maintenance and continual improvement of shipboard instrumentation. This includes both permanently-installed shipboard instrumentation as well as the many kinds of mission-specific instruments moved on and off the vessel to meet the research needs of specific cruises.  The Scripps shipboard technical support group  has  supported marine research on ships operated by their home institution since the late 1950's and  stands strongly behind the quality of its work, the training and education of  technicians, and responsiveness to user suggestions. To insure that the work satisfies the requirements of scientists, ship operators and funding agencies, the Arctic Cruise Coordinator surveys the PI's, technical staff deployed on the cruises, and USCG crew to determine the effectiveness of the shipboard instrumentation in meeting the needs of the marine research activities. The Arctic Cruise Coordinator reviews the surveys and produces a report for procurement of new shipboard instrumentation.

During the port period in late 2012 and early 2013, programmers and network engineers from Scripps fully remodeled the computer laboratory on Healy and updated the computer servers and workstations used for data acquisition and display. New computer monitors were installed as a display array on the aft bulkhead of the lab. This gives a universal view of many scientific systems at once. We worked with the Electronic Systems Support Unit (ESU) of the USCG in updating the network hardware and software on the ship. All work proved successful.

Students participate on many research cruises, and the shipboard technicians use available time to demonstrate to students the instrumentation that is on the ship but not being actively used during that cruise. Working with the scientists and crew on each cruise, the shipboard technicians continually improve the methods for performing research at sea. This experience is shared with other members of the group, especially junior staff who have spent less time at sea. Thus, replication of mistakes is avoided and lessons learned from successes are quickly integrated into routine operating procedures.
